person.note: James Hannan (dates as yet unidentified), one of Livingstone\'s three trustees. He worked for Henry Monteith & Co, owners of the Mill at Blantyre.

Reverend William King (1812-1895), Presbyterian minister, a native of Londonderry, Ireland, established the Elgin Association Settlement at Buxton, Western Ontario, for freed and refugee slaves. Livingstone wrote to King on the same day discouraging the idea of sending freed slaves from Canada to Africa partly on the grounds that they would be as susceptible as Europeans to fever. (C&C 1078)

Charles Frederick Mackenzie (1825-1862), from Peeblesshire. In 1860 he headed the new Universities\' Mission to Central Africa (UMCA). He was consecrated Bishop of Central Africa in Cape Town, 1 January 1861. He met Livingstone at Kongone and the party ascended the Shire River and marched to the Shire highlands. He was embroiled in local warfare over slavery and died of fever, 31 January 1862.

div.p: On board "PioneerThe Pioneer, Livingstone\'s steamship, arrived from England on 31 January 1861 while he was at Kongone, one of the mouths of the Zambesi River. The Pioneer was under British Government orders to explore the Ruvoma River. She left Kongone on 4 February 1861 and anchored in the mouth of the Rovuma on 25 February 1861. This letter was penned during that voyage."

I am desired by Mr King to enclose an answer to his communication of 13thSeptrSeptember /60 to you. You will see that I cannot recommend our coloured bretheren brethren to try their skill in Africa We found that our KroomenKroomen, a name given to a people from the West Coast of Africa, famed as boatmen and often employed aboard ships. even from the West Coast suffered from FeverFever was the scourge of African explorers. The term did not usually refer to a specific disease but to a general disorder which might have any number of variants, for instance, malarial or intermittent, remittent, or continual. These variants were held to depend on such things as an individual\'s constitution, the weather, or the local terrain. and it is well known that residence in a healthy climate renders them quite as liable perhaps more so, to be cut off as Europeans a slight attack prostrates them. When lately at Victoria falls my brother had a severe attack - took our remedyLivingstone reported that in 1850 he had adopted the plan of giving quinine with a purgative in cases of fever and was successful in the cases of two of his own children and an English party (\'On fever in the Zambesi. A note from Dr. Livingstone to Dr. M\'William\', Transactions of the Epidemiological Society of London 1859-62, 1: 235). This was the "remedy" Livingstone used thereafter for fever. Hindsight suggests the remedy worked in those cases that were suffering from malaria. Quinine, which had recently been isolated from Peruvian Bark or cinchona, is effective against the malarial parasite transmitted by mosquitoes. and marched next day on foot.
